quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The main learnings from that is, don't take on projects that are going to be six months, a year, because you just generally don't have control over the macro.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Actionable advice to avoid long, macro-dependent product bets where external conditions can derail outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: The challenge with being a product manager is, everybody thinks they can do the job. Anybody who uses the product thinks they have ideas, so at some point in time, you're like, "What is my discipline? What is my science?" The moment you build experimentation, you've now made it scientific.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A mental model for PM craft: differentiate opinion from discipline by grounding decisions in experimentation.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: Strategy is a little bit overrated for product. For most product managers, your strategy should be, "How fast can I go from hypothesis to data?"
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing of product strategy as speed of learning via rapid hypothesis-to-data loops.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We had Larry literally sitting with us saying we can do anything we want Chrome to do and we still didn't manage to build a great messaging product.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A vivid example that even massive resources and executive support don’t guarantee product success.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: If you're building a SaaS app, at some point, your customers will start asking for enterprise features like SAML authentication and SCIM provisioning.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: Highlights a predictable inflection point for SaaS products: enterprise readiness becomes a customer-driven requirement.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: This enables fast authorization checks at enormous scale while maintaining a flexible model that can be adapted to even the most complex use cases.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A concise mental model for what “good” authorization infrastructure should optimize for: speed, scale, and flexibility.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Integrations are mission-critical for AI for two reasons.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: Sets up a clear framework for why integrations matter specifically in AI products (not just nice-to-have ecosystem work).

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: We believe product teams should focus engineering efforts on competitive advantages, not integrations.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: A prioritization principle teams can apply when deciding what to build in-house versus outsource/partner for.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Paragon provides an embedded platform that enables engineers to ship these product integrations in just days instead of months across every use case from rag data ingestion to agentic actions.
quotes.speaker: Brandon Foo
quotes.context: Provides a concrete time-to-ship claim and examples of integration use cases (RAG ingestion and agentic actions).

quotes.topic_title: Why Binance is uniquely fast and flat
quotes.text: Within six months, they became number one. That's unprecedented. That's like launching a search engine today, and then, six months later, beating Google.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A vivid benchmark for just how unusually fast Binance scaled, useful for calibrating what “hypergrowth” can look like.

quotes.topic_title: Why Binance is uniquely fast and flat
quotes.text: CZ, the founder and CEO at one point had 55 direct reports, and his direct reports had about the similar ones. For a large portion of the history of the company, there was just one level between the individual employees and the CEO.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A counterintuitive org-design choice (extreme flatness) presented as a driver of speed and execution at scale.

quotes.topic_title: Why Binance is uniquely fast and flat
quotes.text: The leadership team was there, 11:00 PM every single day, which meant that none of the decisions were blocked for more than 24 hours.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: An operating cadence that enforces decision velocity by design, preventing long stalls on escalations.

quotes.topic_title: Why Binance is uniquely fast and flat
quotes.text: We executed largely based on this concept that I now take with me. I call it running products via daily meeting.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A portable methodology for driving urgent product work through daily leadership review and accountability.

quotes.topic_title: Why Binance is uniquely fast and flat
quotes.text: It's extremely interesting to see that when you have really smart people, you give them really hard problems, you have no constraints on what can you need to solve them, whether it's money, people, except time. Time is always at a premium. People can move mountains in a small amount of time.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical leadership principle: remove constraints except time to unlock extreme ownership and rapid execution.

quotes.topic_title: Being in the details: KYC onboarding at scale
quotes.text: Then it suddenly became regulated, where you would almost have a full KYC flow like a bank. That just meant that the conversion rate dropped from, let's say, 100% to 2%.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A stark data point showing how regulation can crater onboarding conversion and force a step-change in product approach.

quotes.topic_title: Being in the details: KYC onboarding at scale
quotes.text: We had to, literally have this, the top 50 countries, the top 10 document types, this spreadsheet of basically 500 cells, the conversion rate at each level.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for diagnosing KYC onboarding at scale by instrumenting conversion at the country × document-type cell level.

quotes.topic_title: Being in the details: KYC onboarding at scale
quotes.text: Then we go cell by cell based on, let's say if I was running a typical product team, I would say, okay, let's just look at maybe the top 90 percentile of our users, but this was Binance and then CZ is like, "No user left behind. Even that one user in Congo is important because this is financial inclusion for them." Then all of those 500 sales matter, no matter how low their impact to the conversion rate is.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A counterintuitive prioritization philosophy: optimize for edge-case users too, treating inclusion as a product requirement rather than a rounding error.

quotes.topic_title: Being in the details: KYC onboarding at scale
quotes.text: You, of course, cannot do it for every single product, but the concept of, what is the most leveraged decision you could be working on right now? If it is for your growth, it's the onboarding, then you'd better know exact every single screen of the flow, why is there a drop-off and what are your teams doing for it?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical prioritization lens: pick the highest-leverage area (e.g., onboarding) and go deep enough to explain every drop-off and action plan.

quotes.topic_title: Resource scaling and “wow” moments at Google
quotes.text: At one point in time we said, we had a team of 20 people working on KYC and we said, "For the next three months, we want 500."
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A concrete example of extreme resourcing to rapidly unblock a critical product/company priority.

quotes.topic_title: Resource scaling and “wow” moments at Google
quotes.text: Has its downside, but if you're running in this extreme mode and you're less, not as worried about just the team's stress and personal development aspects of it, you're just purely looking at the execution of the product, there's a surprising amount of power that comes with it.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A counterintuitive tradeoff: temporarily prioritizing execution over people-process concerns can create outsized speed in crisis mode.

quotes.topic_title: Resource scaling and “wow” moments at Google
quotes.text: It was a bug in iOS 4. This is a long time ago, which caused every single user to pull their entire Gmail inbox, re-sync the whole inbox.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A vivid incident showing how external platform bugs can trigger massive, unexpected load and require rapid operational response.

quotes.topic_title: Resource scaling and “wow” moments at Google
quotes.text: A bug on the Apple side is going to take two, three weeks to fix, and it was causing 1000x load to our servers.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A specific data point (1000x load) illustrating why teams must be able to scale infrastructure quickly even when the root cause is outside their control.

quotes.topic_title: Resource scaling and “wow” moments at Google
quotes.text: It's less about having the 500 people and being able to maneuver them that quickly.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical mental model: agility comes from the ability to redeploy resources fast, not just from headcount.

quotes.topic_title: When extreme operating models work (and why)
quotes.text: There are several preconditions. One is you're growing really fast.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Sets up a clear framework that “extreme” operating models only work under specific conditions, starting with hypergrowth.

quotes.topic_title: When extreme operating models work (and why)
quotes.text: The best way to grow in general is that you work at a very fast-growing company.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Actionable career advice: prioritize environments where scale and rate of change accelerate learning more than management structure does.

quotes.topic_title: When extreme operating models work (and why)
quotes.text: If that's true, two, your people are extremely well compensated, so they care about the KPIs more than they care about what's the next stage in my career and how do I get promoted?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Counterintuitive incentive insight: strong comp can shift motivation from title-chasing to outcomes/KPIs.

quotes.topic_title: When extreme operating models work (and why)
quotes.text: Our bonus structure went from 0% to 500%, so a lot of people didn't really care getting a 10%, 20% pay.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Concrete example/data point illustrating how extreme incentives can change behavior and focus.

quotes.topic_title: When extreme operating models work (and why)
quotes.text: A lot of people go through, "Hey, I'm going to move mountains because it's not just about the money, it's just not about my career. It's about doing something that will change the world."
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Memorable articulation of mission-driven motivation as a force multiplier in high-intensity cultures.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration advice for product managers
quotes.text: I think the number one thing I shared before, the best thing you can do is find companies that are growing fast because it compounds your learning at a much faster interval.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A clear career-acceleration heuristic: prioritize environments where learning cycles compound quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration advice for product managers
quotes.text: Some of the products I worked on during my internship had not shipped till I left Microsoft three, four years later. That's a very, very low rate of compounding.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A concrete example illustrating how slow shipping dramatically reduces learning velocity early in a career.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration advice for product managers
quotes.text: Formally in the camp that you need to know what you're great at, what are your superpowers, and you need to find jobs where success is determined by how much of that superpowers you get to use.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A strengths-first role selection framework: choose jobs where your “superpowers” are the primary success driver.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration advice for product managers
quotes.text: Thirdly, largely I would say do not optimize for compensation, especially early in your career.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Counterintuitive guidance that challenges the common early-career focus on maximizing pay.

quotes.topic_title: Career acceleration advice for product managers
quotes.text: There are two jobs. Look at the three things. Is it going to give me high compounding of learning? Is it high overlap with my strengths, and am I going to have a lot of fun doing it?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical decision rubric for choosing between roles using learning rate, strengths fit, and enjoyment.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking the C-level path and “work-life” framing
quotes.text: It's like, if you truly enjoy your work and what you're doing, it won't feel like a sacrifice.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Reframes the executive path away from “sacrifice” toward intrinsic motivation as the deciding factor.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking the C-level path and “work-life” framing
quotes.text: When you're constantly, when you look at a new product, you're walking down the street, you see a new product, you're on the app store, you see a new product, and you're like, "Oh, this is cool. Oh, look how they're doing the onboarding. Oh, look how the app store entry looks."
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Gives a concrete behavioral signal—compulsive curiosity about products—that indicates fit for high-intensity product leadership.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking the C-level path and “work-life” framing
quotes.text: The moment you start having those conversations, you are probably not on that track. You should not be on that track because the moment the word work-life balance comes, I think Jeff Bezos has this thing that he hates the word because it means there are opposite things that need to be balanced, right?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A contrarian filter: if you’re framing it as “work vs life,” you may be mismatched for the executive track.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking the C-level path and “work-life” framing
quotes.text: It needs to be work-life awesomeness or something like that, where every moment is awesome whether you're working or you're living.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Offers a memorable alternative mental model to “balance” that emphasizes integration and sustained energy.

quotes.topic_title: Rethinking the C-level path and “work-life” framing
quotes.text: Whereas for everything else, it would feel like a sacrifice, could feel like something you need to balance. And then you would, again, even if you're great at it, you're not going to have fun doing it, and at some point you will not be great at it.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Warns that even high performance can decay over time if the work drains you—making enjoyment a long-term performance prerequisite.

quotes.topic_title: Alternative career paths beyond climbing to CPO
quotes.text: The challenges with founding a company is a large portion of running a company has nothing to do with building a great product, especially as the company gets bigger.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A reality-check for PMs considering founding: the job shifts away from product work as the company scales.

quotes.topic_title: Alternative career paths beyond climbing to CPO
quotes.text: the thing they tell me when they hire me is, "I wish I had your job," because that's what I used to do. That's what I have loved doing, and now I spend 90% of my time doing stuff that is not the stuff that I truly enjoy.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A vivid example of how executive roles can become dominated by non-product work, even for founders.

quotes.topic_title: Alternative career paths beyond climbing to CPO
quotes.text: If you're constantly hitting that, then founding is a great path for you because then you have the ball control for better or worse.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A decision rule: if lack of control is your recurring blocker, founding may fit because you own outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: Alternative career paths beyond climbing to CPO
quotes.text: The other is just, I mean, it's less about being a CPO and just growing your breadth and your depth instead of just the ladder, right?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A career framework that reframes progression away from titles toward breadth/depth development.

quotes.topic_title: Alternative career paths beyond climbing to CPO
quotes.text: My identity is, who am I as a parent? Who am I as a community member? Who am I as a son to my parents? Who am I as an artist or a contributor? And that's what my death is going to be, a well-rounded person.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A countercultural model for career choices: intentionally decenter work as the core of identity and meaning.

quotes.topic_title: Why N26 produces strong PMs (and fintech effect)
quotes.text: So, a lot of the problems we saw in early days, nobody else saw them, right? So, every product manager had to solve it for the very first time in history. And that kind of is a whole different level of kind of trial by fire.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Highlights why category-defining companies accelerate PM growth: you’re forced to invent solutions without precedents.

quotes.topic_title: Why N26 produces strong PMs (and fintech effect)
quotes.text: So, that success, a mutual success, which a lot of early startup see, that creates kind of a more denser network than you working at a large company where not all of you see the success at the same time.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Explains a career advantage of early high-growth startups: shared wins create unusually strong alumni networks for future leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Why N26 produces strong PMs (and fintech effect)
quotes.text: That being access to these people directly is extremely, extremely empowering. You not just learn from it, but you get inspired by it. If you have an X definition of success, now your definition of success is 10x, you automatically push the boundaries more.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical model for why proximity to exceptional founders raises ambition and expands what teams attempt.

quotes.topic_title: Why N26 produces strong PMs (and fintech effect)
quotes.text: Here's the thing about FinTech, which is probably the most interesting is, FinTech, you have two customers. You have your usual customers and you have your regulator, and you need to keep both of them happy.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for fintech PM work: product decisions must satisfy both users and regulators.

quotes.topic_title: Why N26 produces strong PMs (and fintech effect)
quotes.text: In most PMs, in most companies you have some trade-offs, but they're not existential. Whereas in FinTech, every trade-off is existential.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Counterintuitive framing that explains why fintech can produce strong PMs: the cost of mistakes is survival-level, sharpening judgment.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your strengths (tools and signals)
quotes.text: So, at a Agoda, we used to pay a psychologist $5,000 for every single PM we interview, right? So, after you finish your PM rounds, we would send you to this psych assessment. It would be a six-hour psych assessment and they would tell me what your strengths are, not just that it would be an IQ component.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A concrete, extreme example of using rigorous psychometrics to identify strengths (and hiring signals) beyond interviews.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your strengths (tools and signals)
quotes.text: The way it works, slightly differently for executives because you do it, so those are your components, tells you how good you think you are, and then it has your leadership team vote you on certain different aspects. So, there's a two layer assessment, how good you think you are and how good everybody else think you are.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical 360-style methodology for triangulating strengths by comparing self-perception with peer perception.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your strengths (tools and signals)
quotes.text: And then, the overlap is where your true strengths are.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for identifying “real” strengths as the intersection of self-assessment and others’ assessments.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your strengths (tools and signals)
quotes.text: And you just know when you do these things, which ones one you're truly great at and you have a lot of fun doing, right?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: Actionable self-observation heuristic: track which core PM activities energize you as a signal of strengths.

quotes.topic_title: How to identify your strengths (tools and signals)
quotes.text: And then, when you look at the next job, just try and gauge, are they hiring me because I did really well at some of the stuff that I didn't love doing? And if that's what they're hiring you for, probably you're not going to have a lot of fun or high acceleration if you go there.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A career-alignment filter to avoid roles that reward you for tasks you’re good at but don’t enjoy—reducing long-term performance risk.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy is overrated: prioritize hypothesis-to-data speed
quotes.text: A product, you have hypotheses and if you can test it, you don't need a strategy.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A contrarian reframing: fast, testable hypotheses can replace traditional “strategy” work for many product decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy is overrated: prioritize hypothesis-to-data speed
quotes.text: And if you're really executing fast enough in a kind of structured, experimentation-driven manner, your strategy becomes a largely solved problem.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A methodology claim that operational excellence in experimentation reduces the need for heavy upfront strategic planning.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy is overrated: prioritize hypothesis-to-data speed
quotes.text: All of it is largely in some sort of package intuition. And the challenge with that is, usually you go with the loudest voice in the room.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A warning that “strategy” discussions often mask intuition and devolve into politics unless grounded in evidence.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy is overrated: prioritize hypothesis-to-data speed
quotes.text: He had this one thing he would say all the time that, "Come to me with data. If you come to me with ideas, we'll go with mine."
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A memorable rule-of-thumb for decision-making culture: data is the only reliable way to override senior opinions.

quotes.topic_title: Strategy is overrated: prioritize hypothesis-to-data speed
quotes.text: But for most product managers, your strategy should be, how fast can I go from hypothesis to data, right? The faster you can go there, the easier your strategy gets.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical operating metric for PMs: optimize the cycle time from idea to evidence to make strategy clearer.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing experimentation and making product scientific
quotes.text: But if you're running proper experiments, I just look at the Statsig dashboards, right? And I'm looking at experiments, I'm looking at what metrics they're moving, I'm looking at the P-value, I'm looking at how quickly can they get to statistical significance. And I'm like, "Oh, this is working. Let's do more of these." Right?
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence for prioritization: use experiment dashboards and statistical signals to decide what to scale.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing experimentation and making product scientific
quotes.text: Those, if there are either irreversible decisions or they're just extremely time-consuming to find out, then do some pre-work.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A decision rule for when not to rely on fast A/B tests and instead invest in upfront analysis.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing experimentation and making product scientific
quotes.text: We look at largely, find a lot of companies that really look at data without looking at cohorts that make completely bad decisions, right, because if you look at your dashboard as a mixture of users over 10 years, 20 years, even six months, and they all behave differently.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A warning against aggregate dashboards and a push toward cohort-based analysis to avoid misleading conclusions.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing experimentation and making product scientific
quotes.text: If you measure it as an experiment, you would know that, yeah, between the variant and control, it's still doing great, even though overall conversion is down.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A practical example of experiments protecting teams from misattributing macro effects (e.g., market crashes) to product changes.

quotes.topic_title: Operationalizing experimentation and making product scientific
quotes.text: The moment you build experimentation, you'll now make it scientific, right? Now, somebody comes up with an idea, say, that's a bad idea. Here, this is why it's a bad idea, because we have done this experiment six times and it has failed across this user groups at this exact level of impact created.
quotes.speaker: Mayur Kamat
quotes.context: A methodology for professionalizing product work: experimentation creates a defensible “science” that elevates PM decision-making.
